awd_titl_txt: Collaborative research:   Shock interaction with a complex hydrodynamic medium
awd_abstract_narration:
PI:  Vorobieff, Peter / Jacobs, Gustaaf
Proposal Number: 1603915 / 1603326

When a gas moves at high speeds, a pressure shock is often formed. A comprehensive study that involves experiments and computations is proposed for the case when small particles are also present. Practical applications of the proposed work are found in a plethora of engineering technologies that involve mixing, such as supersonic and hypersonic combustion, and dust explosions (in coal mines and in grain or sugar silos). For example, in combustion applications, incomplete mixing of gas-solid/liquid flows is directly responsible for performance losses and increased environmental pollution.

It is proposed to study shock-driven instabilities in particle-laden flows, where large-scale density gradients are present in the gas phase simultaneously with presence of the particle phase, and the latter may account for a significant fraction of the volume-averaged density. The proposed effort aims to overcome the current disconnect between the studies of the purely hydrodynamic features of shock-driven media (Richtmyer-Meshkov instabilities (RMI), secondary instabilities, and transition to turbulence) and multiphase features of the same flows. By combining computational analysis, experiment and theoretical and model developments, a benchmark set will be developed to prepare for a detailed investigation of the relevant physics, not just in terms of gross flow behavior, but with focus on subtler mixing phenomena induced by baroclinic and particle-gas interaction mechanisms. Experiments will be conducted in the University of New Mexico shock tube, one of the most advanced research facilities of this type in the world. It has a design Mach number of 4 and a highly modular architecture allowing to study shock interaction with a wide variety of objects with minimal reconfiguration. Computations will be conducted with Eulerian-Lagrangian and Eulerian-Eulerian codes based on higher-order Weighted-Essentially-Non-Oscillatory (WENO) schemes that have been developed by the PI at SDSU. The codes will be validated for the interaction of shock and cloud of particles. Effects on flow morphology caused by non-uniformities in the seeding and particle size distribution will be determined. Three-dimensional computations of the complete system and experiment will provide insight into the fully non-linear flow development. A better understanding of the basic physics of shock-driven mixing will lead to improved designs in the energy area, reducing use of natural resources and impact on the environment. The work will engage students from underrepresented groups, encouraging them to pursue long-term careers in STEM-related fields.

por.por_cntn:
We conducted an experimental and numerical study of shock-driven instabilities in particle-laden flows. The goal of the effort was to overcome the disconnect between the studies of the purely

hydrodynamic features of shock-driven media (Richtmyer-Meshkov instabilities (RMI), secondary instabilities, and transition to turbulence) and multiphase features of the same flows. Experiments were run at the University of New Mexico (UNM) shock tube, and numerical simulations ? at San Diego State University (SDSU). The main problem we studied was shock interaction with a nominally planar gravity-driven particle curtain, where massive particles filled about 5% of the total volume. The key finding of the study is that, despite the considerable complexity of the flow observed in experiment, its large-scale behavior can be faithfully reproduced with Eulerian-Lagrangian and Eulerian-Eulerian codes based on higher-order Weighted-Essentially-Non-Oscillatory (WENO) schemes that have been developed at SDSU using a computationally inexpensive one-dimensional setup that disregards such phenomena as particle collisions. Among the most important features observed both in experiment and in numerics was the formation of a reflected pressure wave propagating in the direction opposite to the shock direction. It is also noteworthy that after the shock passage the particle curtain takes a remarkably long time to reach equilibrium velocity (compared with the time it takes the shock to pass through the curtain). The study also produced some unanticipated results. While it is known that multiphase analogs exist for such classical fluid instabilities as RMI or Rayleigh-Taylor instability (RTI), previous observations dealt mostly with flow regimes when the particles were much smaller and accounted for a much lower volume fraction of the flow. For RTI, that flow regime resulted in a behavior that was very similar to classical (single-phase) RTI and that could be described by the same equations (quadratic perturbation amplitude growth). In the case of the impulsively started particle-curtain flow used in our experiments, however, a different trend for the perturbation growth in the falling curtain (linear in a moving reference frame) was observed and analytically explained. The presence of this new instability regime manifests itself in a highly complex non-uniform distribution of particles in the falling curtain on small and intermediate scales, leading to the particle density contour map having robust fractal-like properties characterized with a previously unreported fractal dimension around 7/4.

 

The results were presented at eight talks at the American Physical Society meetings, and a  keynote talk at the 10th International Conference on Computational & Experimental Methods in Multiphase & Complex Flow (Lisbon, 2019). Two peer-reviewed papers have been published, one is accepted for publication, one is pending acceptance. Four graduate students were supported by this grant.
